claim: The story of Betsy Ross designing the first American flag is likely apocryphal.

supporting.text: There is no contemporary documentary evidence from the 1770s that directly links Betsy Ross to the design or creation of the first American flag.

attacks.text: There is no contemporary documentary evidence from the 1770s that directly links Betsy Ross to the design or creation of the first American flag.
Oral tradition and family accounts from Betsy Ross's descendants strongly assert her involvement in designing the first flag.
Oral histories are less reliable than contemporary documents, especially when passed down over generations without corroboration.
The Betsy Ross story was popularized in the 19th century by her grandson, William Canby, who presented it as historical fact based on family lore.
The lack of competing claims or alternative designers during the same period lends indirect credibility to the Betsy Ross narrative.
